general: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 is a law that helps protect people who borrow money from banks or other financial institutions. It makes sure that these lenders follow certain rules and treat their customers fairly. The law also sets up an "ombudsman" who can help resolve disputes between customers and lenders if they cannot come to an agreement on their own. This law is important because it helps ensure that consumers are not taken advantage of by predatory lending practices, and it provides a way for them to seek redress if something goes wrong with their loan.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Act 2006 Overhauls Regulations on Financial Limits and Exemptions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract of the Consumer Credit Act 2006 removes financial limits and introduces new exemptions for certain types of credit agreements.
* Simplified point 2: The exemptions include high net worth individuals, businesses, and unincorporated bodies of persons that do not consist entirely of bodies corporate.
* Simplified point 3: The Act also introduces a new definition of "individual" to include partnerships consisting of two or three persons not all of whom are bodies corporate.
* Simplified point 4: Additionally, the Act allows for exemptions relating to businesses, including agreements entered into wholly or predominantly for business purposes.
* Simplified point 5: The Act makes consequential amendments related to sections 1 to 4, including changes to the definitions of "regulated consumer credit agreements" and "running-account credit."

series.short: "Creditors' Statement Requirements Under the Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 requires creditors to provide regular statements to debtors regarding their fixed-sum credit agreements.
* Simplified point 2: These statements must be given within specific time frames, and the creditor cannot enforce the agreement if they fail to do so.
* Simplified point 3: If the creditor fails to provide a statement within the specified time frame, the debtor has no liability to pay interest or default sums.
* Simplified point 4: The creditor must give the debtor information about the consequences of failing to make payments or only making certain types of payments.
* Simplified point 5: In cases where credit is provided to multiple debtors jointly, the creditor can use "dispensing notices" to exempt them from providing statements to certain debtors.

series.short: "Debt Help: Your Rights and Options Under the Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) must create and distribute two information sheets, one on arrears and another on default, to help debtors and hirers understand their rights and obligations when receiving notices under the Consumer Credit Act 2006.
* Simplified point 2: These information sheets will provide information on how to deal with arrears and default notices, and will be updated every three months to ensure that they remain relevant and useful.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT will give "general notice" of the information sheets, meaning that they will be widely publicized and easily accessible to those who need them.
* Simplified point 4: The information sheets will cover topics such as the consequences of missing payments, how to negotiate with creditors, and what options are available for resolving debt problems.
* Simplified point 5: The regulations governing the content of the information sheets can be changed by the OFT, allowing for flexibility and adaptability in response to changing market conditions and consumer needs.

series.short: "Debt Notifications Under the Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 requires creditors to notify debtors of outstanding payments due under a fixed-sum credit agreement.
* Simplified point 2: The notice must be given within 14 days of the condition being met, and every 6 months after that.
* Simplified point 3: The purpose of the notice is to inform the debtor of the amount they owe and to help them avoid falling behind on their payments.
* Simplified point 4: The notice must include information about the debt, such as the amount owed and the date it is due, as well as information about the creditor's rights and responsibilities.
* Simplified point 5: If the debtor fails to make a payment, the creditor can use the notice to remind them of their obligations and to threaten legal action if necessary.
* Simplified point 6: The notice also serves as a record of the debt and can be used as evidence in court if the matter goes to litigation.

series.short: "Notice Requirements for Missed Payments Under Running-Account Credit Agreements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The creditor must provide the debtor with a notice if they have missed two payments under a running-account credit agreement and certain other conditions are met.
* Simplified point 2: The notice must be given no later than the end of the period within which the creditor is next required to give a statement under section 78(4), and it must include a copy of the current arrears information sheet under section 86A.
* Simplified point 3: The debtor has no liability to pay any sum in connection with the preparation or giving of the notice.
* Simplified point 4: Regulations can make provisions about the form and content of notices under this section.

series.short: "Notice Requirements for Debtors and Creditors"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The creditor/owner cannot enforce the agreement if they fail to give the debtor/hirer notices within the specified time periods.
* Simplified point 2: The debtor/hirer will not be held liable for paying interest or default sums if the creditor/owner fails to give them proper notices.
* Simplified point 3: The period of non-compliance is defined as the time between the end of the notice period and the end of the day when the notice is given to the debtor/hirer.
* Simplified point 4: If the creditor/owner fails to give a notice under Section 86B or 86C, the debtor/hirer will not be held liable for paying interest or default sums during the period of non-compliance.

series.short: "Notice Requirements for Creditors in Debt Agreements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The creditor must send a notice to the debtor within a certain time frame after the default sum becomes payable, informing them of their liability to pay interest on the default sum.
* Simplified point 2: If the creditor fails to send the notice within the specified time frame, they lose their entitlement to enforce the agreement until the notice is given to the debtor.
* Simplified point 3: The debtor has no liability to pay any sums in connection with the preparation or giving of the notice.
* Simplified point 4: Regulations can provide exceptions for small agreements or non-commercial agreements.

series.short: "Consumer Protection: Interest Charges on Default Sum"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation deals with interest charges on default sums owed by debtors or hirers under regulated agreements.
* Simplified point 2: The debtor or hirer will only be required to pay interest on the default sum if it's simple interest, meaning no compound interest will be charged.
* Simplified point 3: The purpose of this section is to protect consumers from excessive interest charges and ensure they are aware of the terms of their agreement.

series.short: "Amendments to Consumer Credit Law: Increased Default Notice Period & Enhanced Communication Flexibility"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The legislation amends the Consumer Credit Act 1974 to increase the time period for a default notice from 7 days to 14 days.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation requires that default notices must now include a copy of the current default information sheet under section 86A.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation expands the contents of default notices to include any other prescribed matters related to the agreement, giving creditors more flexibility in their communication with debtors.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Time Orders: Payment Plans & Notice Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 allows debtors or hirers to apply for time orders to extend the repayment period of their consumer credit agreements.
* Simplified point 2: Before applying for a time order, the debtor or hirer must first give notice to the creditor or owner indicating their intention to make the application and providing details of their proposed payment plan.
* Simplified point 3: The notice must be given after the debtor or hirer has received a notice under sections 86B or 86C of the Act, and a period of at least 14 days must have passed since the date of that notice.
* Simplified point 4: The debtor or hirer can only make an application for a time order through a person who is neither an advocate nor a solicitor, such as a lay representative.
* Simplified point 5: It is an offense for unqualified persons to prepare certain documents related to time orders, including the notice of intention to make an application.

series.short: "Notice Requirement for Post-Judgment Interest Under Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The creditor/owner must give the debtor/hirer a notice within 6 months of the judgment being made, to avoid paying post-judgment interest.
* Simplified point 2: If the creditor/owner fails to give the notice within the 6-month period, the debtor/hirer will not be liable for post-judgment interest.
* Simplified point 3: The notice can be included in a statement or other notice given to the debtor/hirer in relation to the agreement.
* Simplified point 4: Regulations can specify the form and content of the notice.
* Simplified point 5: This section only applies to judgments made under the Consumer Credit Act 2006, and not to other types of judgments.

series.short: "Default Sum Definition Under Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract defines the term "default sum" for the purposes of the Consumer Credit Act 2006. A default sum is a payment due from the borrower/hirer because of a breach of the regulated agreement, but excludes interest.
* Simplified point 2: The definition of default sum only applies to the debtor/hirer and not to other parties involved in the agreement.
* Simplified point 3: The default sum is separate from the default notice, which is defined in the same section of the act.

series.short: "Unfair Credit Relationships: Court's Power to Address Unfairness"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract of the legislation establishes the power of the court to determine if a relationship between a creditor and a debtor is unfair.
* Simplified point 2: The court can make orders to address the unfair relationship, including requiring the creditor to repay sums paid by the debtor or reducing or discharging amounts payable by the debtor.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation applies to credit agreements, including those that are not consumer credit agreements, and covers situations where the creditor has exercised or enforced their rights in an unfair manner.
* Simplified point 4: The court can consider all matters relevant when determining if a relationship is unfair, including matters related to the creditor and the debtor.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation allows the court to make orders even if the relationship has ended.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulations: Licensing Requirements and Enforcement Mechanisms"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract outlines requirements for businesses providing consumer credit or hire services, including obtaining a license and complying with regulations.
* Simplified point 2: Debt administration and credit information services are defined and subject to specific rules regarding licensing and compliance with regulations.
* Simplified point 3: Unlicensed traders cannot enforce regulated agreements against debtors or hirers, but they can apply to the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) for an order to treat the agreements as if they were made by a licensed person.

series.short: "Licensing Fees Under the Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 allows the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to charge applicants for licences or renewals a fee towards the costs of carrying out its functions under the Act.
* Simplified point 2: The amount of the charge is determined by the OFT through general notices, which can include different provision for different types of applicants and provision for no charge at all for certain groups of people.
* Simplified point 3: The approval of the Secretary of State and the Treasury is required for any general notices issued by the OFT under this section.
* Simplified point 4: Applicants for licences or renewals must accompany their applications with the appropriate charge, as set out in the general notices issued by the OFT.
* Simplified point 5: The definition of "costs" in sections 36E(3), 70(4), 73(4), and 75(2) and paragraphs 14 and 15 of Schedule A1 includes expenses incurred in proceedings in Scotland.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Licensing Requirements and Prohibitions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the Consumer Credit Act 2006 deals with the requirements for applying for a standard license to operate a consumer credit business.
* Simplified point 2: The application must specify if the applicant is seeking a license to cover all aspects of the business or just certain parts of it, and the OFT has the power to determine which descriptions of business can be set out in an application.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT also has the power to prohibit applications for certain types of businesses altogether.
* Simplified point 4: The act defines several types of businesses related to consumer credit, including credit brokerage, debt adjusting, debt counseling, debt collecting, and debt administration.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Licensing Requirements in the UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 allows the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to issue standard licenses to individuals who wish to engage in consumer credit activities, provided they meet certain criteria.
* Simplified point 2: To qualify for a standard license, an individual must demonstrate to the OFT that they are a "fit person" to carry on the desired type of business, and that their proposed business practices are not deceitful or oppressive.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT will consider various factors when determining whether an individual is a fit person, including their skills, knowledge, and experience in relation to consumer credit businesses, as well as any evidence of previous offenses or unethical behavior.
* Simplified point 4: If an individual meets these requirements, they will be entitled to a standard license covering the carrying on of the designated type of business, subject to any limitations or restrictions that the OFT deems appropriate.
* Simplified point 5: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 also provides for the issuance of special licenses under certain circumstances, which may include situations where an individual's criminal record or history of non-compliance with consumer credit laws disqualifies them from receiving a standard license.

series.short: "Fit Person Guidance for Office of Fair Trading: Understanding Eligibility Criteria"
series.text:
* The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) is required to provide guidance on how they determine if someone is a "fit person" as defined in Section 25 of the 1974 Act. This guidance will help individuals understand if they meet the criteria set forth in the act.
* The OFT must review and revise their guidance periodically, and publish it in a way that brings it to the attention of those who may be affected by it.
* In creating and updating the guidance, the OFT must consult with relevant parties before doing so.
* The OFT must consider the guidance when performing their duties under this part of the act.

series.short: "License Modifications Allowed Under Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 allows the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to modify standard licenses held by lenders, including removing limitations on the types of businesses they can operate, adding new descriptions of business, or covering additional types of business.
* Simplified point 2: The OFT must receive an application from the licensee before making any changes to their standard license.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT can only make changes to a standard license if the changes are in line with the descriptions of business specified in a general notice under Section 24A(5)(a) of the Act.
* Simplified point 4: If the OFT makes changes to a standard license, it must do so in accordance with the procedures set out in Sections 30 and 31 of the Act.
* Simplified point 5: The OFT cannot revoke or suspend a standard license solely because a person cannot apply for its renewal on the same terms as the existing license.

series.short: "License Termination Provisions Under the Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 allows the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to include provisions in a determination to wind up a standard licensee's business, authorizing the licensee to carry on certain activities for a specified period.
* Simplified point 2: These provisions can specify different periods for different activities or activities of different descriptions, and may provide for persons other than the licensee to carry on activities under the authorization.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT may terminate the authorization from a specified date if a requirement specified under paragraph (c) of subsection (3) is not complied with.
* Simplified point 4: Activities carried on under an authorization shall be treated for the purposes of sections 39(1), 40, 148, and 149 as if carried on under a standard license.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulation Overhaul: New Licensing Requirements & Enhanced FCA Powers"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 introduces new provisions related to consumer credit firms based in the European Economic Area (EEA).
* Simplified point 2: These provisions include requirements for consumer credit EEA firms to hold a standard license, and limitations on the activities they can carry out without a license.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation also includes changes to the process for refusing applications for standard licenses, and adds new powers for the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to intervene in cases where there are concerns about a firm's skills, knowledge, or practices.
* Simplified point 4: Additionally, the legislation updates definitions and references to other laws and regulations to reflect changes in the financial services regulatory framework.

series.short: "License Duration and Fees for Consumer Credit Activities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract of the legislation relates to the duration of licenses issued by the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) for consumer credit activities. It specifies that licenses can either be definite or indefinite, and sets out the procedures for varying their duration.
* Simplified point 2: The extract introduces new provisions for charging fees to licensees with indefinite licenses, and allows for extensions of payment periods in certain circumstances. It also provides for penalties for failure to pay these fees, including termination of the license.

series.short: "Regulatory Powers of the Office of Fair Trading (OFT)"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) can order a licensee to take or stop taking certain actions related to their business if they are unhappy with how the licensee is operating their business.
* Simplified point 2: The OFT can make these orders if they believe that the licensee's actions could harm consumers or if the licensee is not following the terms of their license.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT can also make orders before issuing a standard license to someone who has applied for one, if they believe that the person will not operate their business in a way that benefits consumers.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "associate" in this context includes not just the people listed in Section 184 of the Consumer Credit Act 2006, but also business associates.

* The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) can order a "responsible person" (usually the one who applied for the group license) to change certain practices or procedures related to how they supervise licensees under the group license. This is done when the OFT is unhappy with how the responsible person is regulating or overseeing the licensees.
* The OFT can do this before issuing the group license or after it has been issued.
* A "responsible person" is the original applicant for the group license and has a legal duty to regulate or supervise the licensees.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulations: Supplementary Provisions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section provides supplementary provisions for requirements imposed under sections 33A and 33B of the Consumer Credit Act 2006.
* Simplified point 2: The section allows the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to vary or revoke requirements imposed under sections 33A and 33B, and specifies that the OFT can exercise this power on its own motion or on the application of a person affected by the requirement.
* Simplified point 3: The section also defines who is considered a "person falling within subsection (6)" for the purposes of the requirement, including employees of the person on whom the requirement is imposed.
* Simplified point 4: The section further specifies that the requirement cannot have effect after the license by reference to which it is imposed has ceased to have effect.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulations: Procedural Requirements for Determinations"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 requires the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to follow a specific procedure before imposing any requirements on individuals or businesses.
* Simplified point 2: Before making a determination, the OFT must provide written notice to all affected parties, explaining their reasoning and inviting them to submit representations. This ensures fairness and transparency in the decision-making process.
* Simplified point 3: The notice must be given to anyone who falls within certain criteria set out in the legislation, including those who would fall within sections 33C(6) or (7) as a result of the determination.
* Simplified point 4: The OFT is not required to provide a notice to someone if the determination is in the same terms as a previous proposal made by that person.

series.short: "OFT Guidance on Consumer Credit Act Powers"
series.text:
* The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) is required to provide guidance on how they will use their powers under Sections 33A-33C of the Consumer Credit Act 2006.
* The OFT must publish the guidance in a way that brings it to the attention of those who may be affected by it.
* The OFT must consult with relevant parties before preparing or revising the guidance.
* The OFT must have regard to the most recent version of the guidance when exercising their powers under Sections 33A-33C.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulations: Record Keeping & Appeals Process"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the Consumer Credit Act 2006 outlines the requirements for maintaining records of consumer credit agreements and the process for appealing decisions related to these agreements.
* Simplified point 2: The extract specifies that the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) must keep a register of all consumer credit agreements and provide certain particulars, including any variations made to the agreement. It also establishes appeal processes for determinations made by the OFT regarding requirements imposed under sections 33A and 33B of the Act.
* Simplified point 3: The extract further stipulates that the OFT must provide notice to certain individuals or entities when making determinations related to requirements under sections 33A and 33B, and that these individuals or entities may appeal the determinations if they fall within specified categories.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Application Requirements Under the OFT"
series.text:
* The Consumer Credit Act 2006 requires applicants to provide information and documents to the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) when applying for consumer credit.
* The OFT can issue a notice to the applicant requesting additional information or documents relevant to the application.
* If the application is made after a general notice has come into effect, the applicant must provide any new information or documents that they would have been required to provide had the application been made earlier.
* Applicants must notify the OFT if any information or documents provided in relation to the application are superseded or contain errors.
* The OFT does not require notifications about clerical errors or omissions that do not affect the substance of the information or document.

series.short: "Licensee Notification Requirements Under the Consumer Credit Act 2006"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 requires licensees under a standard licence and original applicants for a group licence to notify the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) of any changes in information or documents provided in relation to an application, including errors or omissions.
* Simplified point 2: The notification must be given within a specified period, usually 28 days, after the change or error is discovered.
* Simplified point 3: The notification requirements do not apply to clerical errors or omissions that do not affect the substance of the information or document.
* Simplified point 4: The OFT can specify descriptions of matters for which notifications are required, and these descriptions must be limited to matters that are relevant to the question of whether a person is a fit person to carry on a business under a standard licence or whether the public interest is better served by a group licence remaining in effect.

series.short: "OFT's Information Request Powers for Consumer Credit Regulation Compliance"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) can request information and documents from individuals and companies to ensure they are complying with consumer credit regulations.
* Simplified point 2: The OFT can make these requests if they have reason to believe that an individual or company has committed an act or omission that casts doubt on their fitness to carry on a business under a standard licence, or if the public interest would be better served by a group licence not being in effect.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT can also request information and documents if there is a likelihood of dissatisfaction among consumers, or if there has been a failure to comply with consumer credit regulations.

series.short: "OFT's Access to Premises Under Consumer Credit Licence"
series.text:
* The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) can request access to the premises of a licensee under a consumer credit licence to observe and inspect documents related to the business being conducted on those premises.
* The OFT can do this to ensure compliance with the Consumer Credit Act 2006 and to gather information for the purposes of its functions under the Act.
* The OFT must provide reasonable notice before accessing the premises and can only do so during business hours.
* The licensee must provide assistance and information to the OFT upon request, including explanations of documents being inspected.
* The power to require access to premises applies to both the licensee and any other person who is involved in the business being observed or inspected.

series.short: "Warrant for Search and Seizure in Consumer Credit Cases"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law allows authorities to enter and search premises with a warrant if they have reason to believe that information or documents related to consumer credit are being hidden or tampered with.
* Simplified point 2: The warrant can authorize officers to seize and detain any relevant information or documents, use reasonable force, and bring along personnel and equipment as needed.
* Simplified point 3: In Scotland, the law refers to a sheriff instead of a justice of the peace, and evidence must be provided on oath instead of information.
* Simplified point 4: In Northern Ireland, the reference to a justice of the peace is construed as a reference to a lay magistrate.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Law: OFT Enforcement & Remedies"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 gives power to the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to apply to the court if a lender fails to provide required information.
* Simplified point 2: If the court finds that the lender has failed to provide the required information, they can order the lender to take action to remedy the situation, such as providing the information within a certain timeframe or paying costs associated with the application.
* Simplified point 3: The law applies to all types of credit agreements, including those between individuals and businesses.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "officer" includes directors, managers, secretaries, and any other similar positions within a company.
* Simplified point 5: In Scotland, the law applies to both the Court of Session and the sheriff.

series.short: "Non-OFT Enforcement Authorities' Powers Restricted"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section restricts officers of non-OFT enforcement authorities from exercising certain powers without prior arrangements with the OFT.
* Simplified point 2: Anything done or omitted by these officers will be considered as if it were done by an OFT officer, except in cases of criminal proceedings.
* Simplified point 3: These officers cannot disclose information obtained through their powers to anyone outside the OFT without explicit approval or a legal obligation to do so.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "relevant officer" refers to officers of non-OFT enforcement authorities.

series.short: The Consumer Credit Act 2006: Penalties for False Information and Documentation Powers
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 outlines penalties for providing false information to the Office of Fair Trading (OFT).
* Simplified point 2: The act defines "documents" to include information recorded in any form, and grants powers to the OFT to require the provision of information or documents, including the power to take copies or extracts.
* Simplified point 3: The act specifies circumstances under which the OFT cannot require the provision of certain types of information, such as legal professional privilege or confidentiality of communications.
* Simplified point 4: The act provides for the seizure of documents at premises, including the power to take copies or extracts, but excludes certain types of information or documents from being subject to these powers.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulations: Penalties for Non-Compliance"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 gives the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) the power to impose civil penalties on individuals or businesses that fail to comply with certain requirements related to consumer credit.
* Simplified point 2: The OFT can impose a penalty of up to £50,000 on those who fail to comply with these requirements, and the penalty can be recovered by the OFT if it remains unpaid.
* Simplified point 3: Before imposing a penalty, the OFT must give notice to the individual or business and invite them to make representations about the matter.
* Simplified point 4: The OFT will consider various factors when deciding whether to impose a penalty, including any previous penalties or fines imposed on the individual or business.
* Simplified point 5: The OFT must publish a statement of policy on how it exercises its powers under section 39A of the Consumer Credit Act 2006, and it must consult with relevant persons before doing so.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulation: Establishment of Ombudsman Scheme"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Appeals Tribunal is created to hear appeals regarding decisions made by the OFT.
* Simplified point 2: The Consumer Credit Jurisdiction allows for complaints related to acts or omissions of licensees under standard licenses to be dealt with under the ombudsman scheme.
* Simplified point 3: Financial services ombudsman scheme will apply to consumer credit licensees.
* Simplified point 4: The OFT can collect contributions from licensees to raise funds for the ombudsman scheme.
* Simplified point 5: Contributions received by the OFT must be paid to the scheme operator.
* Simplified point 6: The Secretary of State can make orders to modify the Consumer Credit Act 1974 to allow for the functions of the OFT to be carried out by the scheme operator.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulation: OFT Powers and Responsibilities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 gives the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) the power to monitor businesses operating under licenses.
* Simplified point 2: The OFT can issue directions to businesses to ensure they comply with the Act's requirements.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT can also vary or revoke any determinations made by them under the Act.
* Simplified point 4: The OFT has the power to determine which consumer hire agreements do not fall under certain provisions of the Act.
* Simplified point 5: The OFT can charge fees, penalties, and other sums to businesses that violate the Act's provisions.

series.short: Consumer Credit Act 2006: Financial Provisions and Transition Arrangements
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section provides for financial provisions related to the Consumer Credit Act 2006, including expenditure incurred by the government and increases in existing spending due to the new act.
* Simplified point 2: It defines key terms used in the act, such as "the 1974 Act" and "the 2000 Act", which refer to previous consumer credit laws.
* Simplified point 3: The Secretary of State can make orders to modify existing acts or instruments to accommodate changes brought about by the Consumer Credit Act 2006.
* Simplified point 4: The section includes provisions for transitional arrangements and savings to ensure a smooth transition to the new law.
* Simplified point 5: The act will be known as the Consumer Credit Act 2006 and will extend to Northern Ireland.

series.short: "New Rules for Consumer Credit Agreements: Increased Protection for Debtors"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: Removes financial limits and introduces new exemptions for certain types of credit agreements.
* Simplified point 2: Exemptions include high net worth individuals, businesses, and unincorporated bodies of persons that do not consist entirely of bodies corporate.
* Simplified point 3: Allows for exemptions relating to businesses, including agreements entered into wholly or predominantly for business purposes.
* Simplified point 4: Requires creditors to provide regular statements to debtors regarding their fixed-sum credit agreements.
* Simplified point 5: Provides information on how to deal with arrears and default notices, and updates every three months to ensure relevance and usefulness.
* Simplified point 6: Requires creditors to notify debtors of outstanding payments due under a fixed-sum credit agreement.
* Simplified point 7: Prohibits creditors from enforcing agreements if they fail to give debtors notices within specified time periods.
* Simplified point 8: Allows debtors to apply for time orders to extend the repayment period of their consumer credit agreements.
* Simplified point 9: Defines the term "default sum" for the purposes of the Consumer Credit Act 2006.
* Simplified point 10: Establishes the power of the court to determine if a relationship between a creditor and a debtor is unfair.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulations: Licensing and Charges"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 empowers the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) to impose charges on applicants for licences or renewals, with the amount determined by the OFT through general notices.
* Simplified point 2: The OFT can require licensees to accompany their applications with the appropriate charge, as set out in the general notices.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT can only make changes to a standard license if the changes are in line with the descriptions of business specified in a general notice under Section 24A(5)(a) of the Act.
* Simplified point 4: The OFT can modify standard licenses held by lenders, including removing limitations on the types of businesses they can operate, adding new descriptions of business, or covering additional types of business.
* Simplified point 5: The OFT can include provisions in a determination to wind up a standard licensee's business, authorizing the licensee to carry on certain activities for a specified period.
* Simplified point 6: The OFT can order a licensee to take or stop taking certain actions related to their business if they are unhappy with how the licensee is operating their business.
* Simplified point 7: The OFT can make orders before issuing a standard license to someone who has applied for one, if they believe that the person will not operate their business in a way that benefits consumers.
* Simplified point 8: The OFT can vary or revoke requirements imposed under sections 33A and 33B of the Consumer Credit Act 2006.

series.short: "Consumer Credit Regulation: Rules for Records and Appeals"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 sets out rules for maintaining records of consumer credit agreements and the process for appealing decisions related to these agreements.
* Simplified point 2: The Act specifies the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) must keep a register of all consumer credit agreements and provide certain particulars, including any variations made to the agreement.
* Simplified point 3: The OFT must provide notice to certain individuals or entities when making determinations related to requirements under sections 33A and 33B of the Act.
* Simplified point 4: Applicants must notify the OFT if any information or documents provided in relation to the application are superseded or contain errors.
* Simplified point 5: The OFT can request information and documents from individuals and companies to ensure compliance with consumer credit regulations.
* Simplified point 6: The OFT can enter and search premises with a warrant if they have reason to believe that information or documents related to consumer credit are being hidden or tampered with.
* Simplified point 7: The Act gives the OFT the power to impose civil penalties on individuals or businesses that fail to comply with certain requirements related to consumer credit.

series.short: Consumer Credit Regulations: Removing Financial Limits & Introducing Exemptions
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Credit Act 2006 removes financial limits and introduces new exemptions for certain types of credit agreements.
* Simplified point 2: The Act exempts high net worth individuals, businesses, and unincorporated bodies of persons that do not consist entirely of bodies corporate.
* Simplified point 3: The Act allows for exemptions relating to businesses, including agreements entered into wholly or predominantly for business purposes.
* Simplified point 4: Creditors must provide regular statements to debtors regarding their fixed-sum credit agreements.
* Simplified point 5: The Act provides information on how to deal with arrears and default notices, and updates every three months to ensure relevance and usefulness.
* Simplified point 6: Creditors must notify debtors of outstanding payments due under a fixed-sum credit agreement.
* Simplified point 7: The Act prohibits creditors from enforcing agreements if they fail to give debtors notices within specified time periods.
* Simplified point 8: Debtors can apply for time orders to extend the repayment period of their consumer credit agreements.
* Simplified point 9: The Act defines the term "default sum" for the purposes of the Consumer Credit Act 2006.
* Simplified point 10: The Act establishes the power of the court to determine if a relationship between a creditor and a debtor is unfair.

summary:
The Consumer Credit Act 2006 improves protections for borrowers by removing financial limits and introducing new exemptions for certain types of credit agreements. This means more people can access credit without worrying about hitting financial limits. High net worth individuals, businesses, and unincorporated bodies of persons that don't consist entirely of bodies corporate may qualify for these exemptions. Additionally, the act requires creditors to provide regular statements to debtors and update them every three months to ensure relevance and usefulness. It also prohibits creditors from enforcing agreements if they fail to give debtors notices within specified time periods. If you're having trouble paying back a loan, you can now apply for time orders to extend the repayment period of your consumer credit agreements. This law helps protect you from unfair relationships with creditors and ensures they follow fair practices.
The Consumer Credit Act 2006 also regulates licensing and charges for those seeking to become licensed credit providers. The Office of Fair Trading (OFT) can impose charges on applicants for licences or renewals, with the amount determined by the OFT through general notices. The OFT can also modify standard licenses held by lenders, remove limitations on the types of businesses they can operate, add new descriptions of business, or cover additional types of business. Furthermore, the OFT can make orders before issuing a standard license to someone who has applied for one, if they believe that the person will not operate their business in a way that benefits consumers.
Lastly, the Consumer Credit Act 2006 sets out rules for maintaining records of consumer credit agreements and the process for appealing decisions related to these agreements. The Act specifies the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) must keep a register of all consumer credit agreements and provide certain particulars, including any variations made to the agreement. The OFT must provide notice to certain individuals or entities when making determinations related to requirements under sections 33A and 33B of the Act.
